At the outset, it should be clarified that Chairman Fiala is talking about Act No. 236/1995 Coll. (abbreviated as the salary of constitutional officials). The so-called automaton , or linking the salary of constitutional officials to the state of the economy, is reflected in the determination of a certain coefficient by which the so-called salary base is multiplied. This is 2.75 times the " average nominal monthly salary of natural persons in the non-business sphere achieved according to published data from the Czech Statistical Office for the calendar year before last " . In other words, for 2019, the salary base is calculated as 2.75 times the average monthly salary for 2017 and determined by the communication of the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs.

The above-described machine itself was already part of Act No. 309/2002 Coll., on amendments to laws related to the adoption of the Act on the Service of Civil Servants in Administrative Offices. At that time, the salary base for representatives designated by the Act was to be three times the average monthly wage for the year before last. The purpose of this establishment was actually to establish a " stable link between the salaries of constitutional officials and the development of wages in the non-business sphere " (.doc, p. 36). The procedural history of this provision then consisted primarily in the several postponements of the effectiveness of this act or the annulment of individual provisions of the Act on the Salary of Constitutional Officials by the Constitutional Court. The final amendment to Act No. 359/2014 Coll. from 2014 comes (.pdf) from the pen of Jan Hamáček, the then Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies. The original government proposal (Bohuslav Sobotka's government) envisaged (.pdf) a fixed salary of CZK 52,248 for the next four years, and in the end, Hamáček's amendment was accepted instead.

The new salary range was thus determined by determining a new multiple for deputies (2.75) and a special multiple for judges (3.00). Given the difference between the fixed amount for 2014 and the amount given by the multiple in 2015, Hamáček's proposal provided for a gradual annual increase in the multiple over four years. The salary base should thus reach 2.5 times the average wage for the year before last in 2018.

Petr Fiala and the entire ODS did not vote for either Hamáček's amendment or the final wording of the law . The majority abstained, and in the second vote two deputies were against. Therefore, the expression " we agreed " used by Chairman Fiala in his statement is somewhat questionable.

As for the meaning of the statement about " creating a solution that we will not have to return to ", the amendment may directly imply an effort after 2018 (when the salary was calculated by a multiple of 2.5) to immediately jump to calculating with a multiple of 2.75 in the following year. According to data from Czech Television (infobox note), however, such a procedure would cause the salary of a deputy and senator to increase by 14,700 CZK. The government, which proposed an amendment to the Act on the Salaries of Constitutional Officials, is probably aware of this. Fiala speaks about two things in his statement. According to him, the Global Compact on Migration is a vague document and ceases to distinguish between legal and illegal migration. As a second fact, he states that the same objections to this document are heard from other European countries. We do not take the phrase “most European countries” literally, but only verify whether these views appear in a larger number of countries.

The Global Compact states that this document is not legally binding (p. 2, point 7). This is a declaration that does not contain any sanctions, and this type of document contains general principles rather than specific commitments.

As for the distinction between legal and illegal migration, the Covenant allows states to do so. “ States may distinguish between legal and illegal migration status (...) ” (paragraph 15, p. 4). However, it is a fact that in some points of the document the distinction between these statuses is no longer made. It is best to show this by example. For example, the signatories to the agreement declare in it (paragraph 13 h, p. 21) that they want to “ protect and respect the rights and best interests of the child at all times, regardless of their migration status, by ensuring the availability of viable alternatives to detention in detention facilities. Priority is given to community-based care, ensuring access to education and health care, and respecting the right of children to family life and family unity (...) ”. According to this point, it should not matter to states whether a child entered the country legally or illegally. What matters is the best interests of the child and states should treat both types of child migrants equally.

Now to the very core of our assessment, namely the question of whether similar objections to those of the ODS leader are also being raised in other European countries.

Looking at neighboring Austria , for example, Austrian Chancellor Kurz announced that his country would not join the Global Compact. He stated that the Global Compact does not help to solve migration issues, threatens Austrian sovereignty in matters of migration policy, and blurs the distinction between legal and illegal migration. Austria also raised doubts about the interpretation of certain passages, for example whether the compact can be interpreted as a provision on migration as a human right.

Poland has also announced its intention not to join the Global Compact. Polish Interior Minister Brudzinski stated that the reasons for this step were that " in our opinion, the draft agreement does not guarantee Poland's security. Moreover, it may increase illegal migration . "

The document is also being discussed in Germany . The opposition AfD party, for example, is against its adoption, but there are also critical voices from the ruling CDU/CSU. For example, MP Wendt is concerned about the lack of distinction between refugees and labor migration, while his colleague Mitsch is concerned that the Global Pact " will curtail Germany's sovereignty in migration issues ."

Doubts about the interpretation were also voiced in Estonia , where some political parties demanded that the government clarify the country's political position, i.e. prevent abuse of the ambiguous pact. The Slovak discussion then shows the uncertainty of individual parties and politicians regarding how the Pact can be understood and what obligations it brings to the signatories.

President Miloš Zeman stated the following on TV Barrandov on October 24, 2019 (time 6:27): "Let Mr. Koudelka focus on economic crime in the Czech Republic instead of fictitiously chasing Russian and Chinese spies."

The President also responded to the speech of the Director of the Security Information Service, Michal Koudelka, in the Chamber of Deputies on October 21, 2019. He stated that the BIS and the National Center for Organized Crime (NCOZ) had last year uncovered and dismantled a spy network that was being built in the Czech Republic by the Russian intelligence service. The Russian Embassy denied this claim.

The BIS annual report from 2017 also talks about Russian and Chinese influence. The report talks about two cyberattacks on the Foreign Ministry (.pdf, pp. 15-16), about the "infiltration" of the Russian diplomatic mission by people with contacts in intelligence services (pp. 6-8), but also about disinformation websites (pp. 7-8).

A BIS spokesperson defended himself against Miloš Zeman's statement of October 24, 2019, saying: "The fight against corruption is not within the legal competence of the BIS. This issue is addressed by special units of the Czech Police."

The status and scope of the BIS are determined by Act No. 153/1994 Coll. on the Intelligence Services of the Czech Republic. According to Section 5, the BIS provides information on activities whose consequences may threaten the security or significant economic interests of the Czech Republic. According to the official website of the BIS, a significant economic interest is understood to be an interest in the functionality of systems with a broad economic reach and in the optimal management of assets, the loss of which could threaten the basic functions of the state. The explanatory memorandum to the Act on Intelligence Services speaks of the need to " detect through intelligence efforts also efforts directed against the mechanisms of the financial and economic functioning of the state in cases where their consequences may damage the interests of the Czech Republic". These economic interests may be influenced, among other things, by illegal activities, which can include corruption, although it is not explicitly mentioned in the law or on the BIS website.

It cannot be ruled out that a specific case of corruption that would significantly threaten the economic interests of the Czech Republic could fall within the scope of the BIS. However, in general, the fight against economic crime is not within the scope of the BIS. This is investigated by specialized units of the Czech Police, for example, the Corruption and Financial Crime Detection Unit or the Organized Crime Detection Unit of the SKPV.

Determine whether the statement is TRUE or FALSE based on the content and a number of short explanations with additional information. Only one of the following explanations is relevant: SECTION A:

In his statement, Minister Jurečka describes the mechanism of extraordinary pension valorization, which, according to the Pension Insurance Act, will be used in the event of rapidly increasing inflation.

The conditions for increasing pensions in an extraordinary period are specifically described in Section 67. According to it, an extraordinary valorization of pensions is applied if the growth of the consumer price index has reached at least 5%. The merit part of the pension (i.e. the percentage assessment of the pension) is then increased by the same percentage as the price increase.

The period for determining price increases always begins with the calendar month following the end of the period according to which pensions were last valorized. In the case of a regular valorization date, price increases are monitored until the end of June of the previous year (in the case of a regular date in 2022, this would be the end of June 2021). However, in the case of an extraordinary valorization , the assessed period is shortened and ends with the month " in which price increases reached at least 5%. Let us specify that these 5% must be the sum of "month-on-month inflation increases " for the given period.

Pensions are increased on a regular basis from January 1. The last increase took place on January 1, 2022, based on the increase in the consumer price index by the end of June 2021 (.pdf). The last month "taken into account for pension valorization" was June, not July, which Marian Jurečka mentions in his statement. However, let us note that the period for determining price increases for further pension increases begins in July 2021.

The whole issue is also explained in a press release ( .pdf ) of the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs from November 18, 2021. According to this report, pensions must be increased by a government decree if the above conditions are met. The government must issue this within 50 days of the end of the month in which prices increased by at least 5%. If the estimates come true, according to the ministry, the pension increase should take place in June 2022 (.pdf).

In January, the spokesperson for the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs , Eva Davidová , also commented on the extraordinary valorization of pensions for the daily Právo: " We assume that there will be such a price increase in January that the cumulated inflation from July 2021 will exceed five percent and that the valorization will be carried out in an extraordinary period, which will include the entire price development until January 2022." She also added that the regular valorization of pensions in 2023 will be lower than if the extraordinary valorization had not occurred, but overall, both pension increases will reflect the overall price development.

As for the overall growth of the consumer price index , from July to November 2021, this value increased by 3.1% . In December, there was a month-on-month increase of 0.4% , bringing the total number to 3.5%. The Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs is therefore likely counting on an even faster increase of at least 1.5% in January, to a total of 5%.

Let us add that the Ministry of Finance, in its January macroeconomic prediction, expects a relatively sharp increase in the average inflation rate to 8.5% in 2022. According to information from the Czech Statistical Office, in 2021 it was 3.8% .

Given that Marian Jurečka describes the applicable rules for extraordinary valorization correctly, apart from a minor time inaccuracy, we assess this statement as true.
